title: Case Study 10
chief_complaint: I've been having dizzy spells for the last 3 months and I'm having trouble hearing, especially in my left ear. I also hear a buzzy sound and my ear feels full.

problem_summary.course: Episodic vertigo; chronic perforation in right ear.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral findings (Right perforation, Left hearing loss/symptoms).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Hearing difficulties reported, particularly in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of vertigo and hearing status.

history.present_illness: Patient referred by ENT for evaluation due to episodes of vertigo over the past 3 months. ENT noted a perforation in the right ear. Patient reports hearing difficulties (Left > Right), tinnitus ('buzzy'), and aural fullness.
history.otologic_history: Right ear perforation noted by physician.
history.noise_exposure_history: Denied excessive noise exposure on a regular basis.
history.medical_psych_history: Denied family history of hearing loss.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of vertigo and hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss rising to normal limits in the high frequencies with a significant air-bone gap in the lows. Left ear shows a mild-to-moderate relatively flat sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition in the right ear; good/fair word recognition in the left ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Type B with large ear canal volume (consistent with perforation). Left ear: Type A (normal).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Wideband reflectance: Right ear shows very low reflectance across the frequency range (consistent with perforation). Left ear shows normal reflectance pattern.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the right ear, consistent with the known tympanic membrane perforation (confirmed by large volume Type B tympanogram). The left ear exhibits a mild-to-moderate flat sensorineural hearing loss with reduced word recognition (84%). The constellation of left-sided SNHL, tinnitus, aural fullness, and episodic vertigo is clinically significant.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms two different conditions affecting your ears.
In the right ear, the hole in the eardrum (perforation) is preventing sound from carrying efficiently, causing a mild hearing loss in the low pitches.
In the left ear, you have a nerve-related hearing loss. This, combined with the buzzing sound, fullness, and dizziness you described, suggests an inner ear condition that we need to manage medically.
It is important to keep your right ear dry to prevent infection due to the perforation.
We will coordinate with your ENT physician regarding the management of the dizziness and the perforation.
notes_for_actor: You are experiencing 'buzzy' noise and fullness specifically in your LEFT ear, even though the doctor mentioned a hole in your RIGHT ear.
If asked about the dizziness, describe it as spinning sensations (vertigo) that come and go.
